intro: Reissantia cassinoides, commonly known as the Mexican elder or Mexican persimmon, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the family Cornaceae and is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves and clusters of small, greenish-white flowers. The plant produces small, round fruits that are typically yellow or orange when ripe. It is often found in tropical and subtropical regions, growing in moist, well-drained soils. Reissantia cassinoides is valued for its ornamental appeal and has been used in traditional medicine for various purposes.
